p: We can elucidate this result by considering the role of the stochastic step in the rate of emergence. Figure 4 shows the probability a strain emerges for a particular effective reproductive ratio, R 1 = χ R 0 S/ N, equal to 1 − P 1 in equation ( 2.3). As R 1 decreases towards 1, it becomes less likely a new strain will emerge at that step. If S were fixed this would imply that, for each R 0, there is a critical value of χ below which the appearance of strains is relatively rare. Although a subsequent compensatory mutation and emergence event can still occur, as shown by the solid line in figure 4, this is rare for R 1 < 1 and the long wait for the appearance of a new strain slows down the rate of emergence.
